abstract.text: A queue of payment transactions for the App Store to process.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The payment queue communicates with the App Store and presents a user interface so that the user can authorize payment. The contents of the queue are persistent between launches of your app.
To process a payment, first add at least one observer object (
) for the item the user wants to purchase. Each time you add a payment object, the queue creates a transaction object (

) to process that payment and enqueues it to be processed. After payment is fulfilled, the queue updates the transaction object and then calls any observer objects to provide them the updated transaction. Your observer should process the transaction and then remove it from the queue.
The exact mechanism you use to process a processed transaction depends on the design of your app and the product being purchased. Here are a few common examples:
If the product is a feature already built into your app, your app enables the feature to process the transaction.
If the product includes downloadable content provided by the App Store, your app retrieves the

objects from the transaction and ask the payment queue to download them. You provide the actual content files to be served by the App Store to App Store Connect when you create the product information.
If the product represents downloadable content provided by your own server, your app might open a network connection to your server and download the content from there.
For more information on designing the payment processing portion of your app, see

abstract.text: Support In-App Purchases and interactions with the App Store.
Downloadable content associated with a product.
A request to the App Store to process payment for additional functionality that your app offers.
A queue of payment transactions for the App Store to process.
Adds a payment request to the queue.
Adds an observer to the payment queue.
A method that indicates whether the person can make purchases.
Removes a set of downloads from the download list.
Returns the default payment queue instance.
A delegate that provides information needed to complete transactions.
Notifies the App Store that the app finished processing the transaction.
Pauses a set of downloads.
Displays a sheet that enables customers to redeem subscription offer codes that you configure in App Store Connect.
Removes an observer from the payment queue.
Asks the payment queue to restore previously completed purchases.
Asks the payment queue to restore previously completed purchases, providing an opaque identifier for the user’s account.
Resumes a set of downloads.
Asks the system to display the price consent sheet if the user hasn’t yet responded to a subscription price increase.
Adds a set of downloads to the download list.
The App Store storefront of the device.
An array of all active payment queue observers.
Returns an array of pending transactions.
The protocol that provides information needed to complete transactions.
An object in the payment queue.
A set of methods that process transactions, unlock purchased functionality, and continue promoted In-App Purchases.
An abstract class that represents a request to the App Store.
Fetch, display, purchase, validate, and finish transactions in your app.

abstract.text: Give customers functionality that restores their purchases in your app to maintain access to purchased content.
Enable your app to receive and handle transactions by adding an observer.

abstract.text: Verify that your app activates its payment transaction observer by using breakpoints.
Deliver content to the customer after validating the purchase.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
